title: Partnerships
description: Partnerships flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.backPlain: There are three types of partnerships that may arise on essays. 1. General partnership: any association of two or more people as co-owners of a for-profit business. 1.1 Formation: no formal agreement is required; the parties' intent to associate as co-owners can be inferred from their conduct. 1.2 Liability: all partners are personally and jointly liable for all partnership debts. 2. Limited liability partnership (LLP): a partnership in which partners' potential for personal liability is limited. 3. Limited partnership (LP): a partnership with different levels of partners (at least one general partner and at least one limited partner). 4. Note on partnership rules: the rules on these cards generally apply to all partnership types, unless otherwise noted. These are default rules, but partnership agreements can create different rights, duties, and obligations.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three main types of partnerships, and how do they differ in formation and liability?
cards.cloze: There are three types of partnerships that may arise on essays. 1. {{c1::General partnership}}: any association of two or more people as co-owners of a {{c2::for-profit business}}. 1.1 Formation: no {{c3::formal agreement}} is required; the parties' intent to associate as co-owners can be {{c4::inferred from their conduct}}. 1.2 Liability: all partners are {{c5::personally and jointly liable}} for all partnership debts. 2. {{c6::Limited liability partnership (LLP)}}: a partnership in which partners' potential for {{c7::personal liability}} is {{c8::limited}}. 3. {{c9::Limited partnership (LP)}}: a partnership with different levels of partners (at least one {{c10::general partner}} and at least one {{c11::limited partner}}). 4. Note on partnership rules: the rules on these cards generally apply to all partnership types, unless otherwise noted. These are {{c12::default rules}}, but {{c13::partnership agreements}} can create different rights, duties, and obligations.
cards.easyContent: There are three basic types of partnerships: general partnerships, LLPs, and LPs. General partners are personally and jointly liable for partnership debts; LLPs and LPs limit some or all partners’ personal liability by statute.
cards.mediumContent: Partnerships on the bar include: (1) general partnerships, which are associations of two or more people as co-owners of a for‑profit business, formed without formalities and imposing personal, joint liability for partnership debts; (2) limited liability partnerships (LLPs), which are partnerships where partners’ personal liability is limited; and (3) limited partnerships (LPs), which have at least one general partner and at least one limited partner, with differing liability and management roles. Partnership rules are default rules that can be altered by agreement, unless otherwise stated by statute.
cards.hardContent: There are three types of partnerships that may arise on essays. A general partnership is any association of two or more people as co-owners of a for‑profit business. No formal agreement is required; the parties’ intent to associate as co‑owners can be inferred from their conduct. In a general partnership, all partners are personally and jointly liable for all partnership debts. A limited liability partnership (LLP) is a partnership in which the partners’ potential for personal liability is limited by statute. A limited partnership (LP) is a partnership with different levels of partners, typically at least one general partner, who manages and has personal liability, and at least one limited partner, who has limited liability and usually no management authority. The partnership rules discussed on these cards generally apply to all partnership types unless otherwise noted. These are default rules that can be modified by a valid partnership agreement, subject to mandatory statutory limits.
cards.mnemonic: GLL: General, Limited Liability, Limited partnerships.
cards.clozeLite: Bar partnerships: {{c1::general partnership}} (no formalities, {{c2::personal joint liability}}); {{c3::LLP}} (partners’ {{c4::liability limited by statute}}); {{c5::LP}} ({{c6::general vs limited partners}}).

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.backPlain: A partnership is formed when two or more people associate to carry on a for-profit business as co-owners. No formal written agreement or use of the label “partnership” is required; intent can be inferred from conduct. To determine whether a partnership exists, courts look primarily to whether the parties intended to carry on a business as co-owners, and then to objective factors such as profit-sharing, control, capital contributions, and joint ownership of property. Even if no actual partnership exists, parties may still be liable to third parties as if they were partners under the doctrine of partnership by estoppel when they hold themselves or others out as partners or consent to being so held out.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a partnership, in broad terms, and what are the main ways its existence or appearance can arise (including partnership by estoppel)?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::partnership}} is formed when {{c2::two or more people}} associate to carry on a {{c3::for-profit business}} as {{c4::co-owners}}. No {{c5::formal written agreement}} or use of the label “partnership” is required; intent can be {{c6::inferred from conduct}}. To determine whether a partnership exists, courts look primarily to whether the parties {{c7::intended to carry on a business as co-owners}}, and then to objective factors such as {{c8::profit-sharing}}, {{c9::control}}, {{c10::capital contributions}}, and {{c11::joint ownership of property}}. Even if no actual partnership exists, parties may still be liable to third parties as if they were partners under the doctrine of {{c12::partnership by estoppel}} when they {{c13::hold themselves or others out as partners}} or {{c14::consent to being so held out}}.
cards.easyContent: A partnership is a for‑profit business carried on by two or more co‑owners. No formal agreement is required; courts infer a partnership from intent and factors like profit‑sharing and control. Even without a real partnership, parties can be liable as partners if they hold themselves out as partners (partnership by estoppel).
cards.mediumContent: A partnership is formed when two or more people associate to carry on a for‑profit business as co‑owners, even without a formal agreement or express intent to be in a “partnership.” Courts focus on whether the parties intended to run a business as co‑owners and consider factors such as profit‑sharing, control, capital contributions, and joint ownership of property. Separately, under partnership by estoppel, parties who hold themselves or others out as partners, or consent to being held out, can be liable to third parties who rely on that representation, even if no actual partnership exists.
cards.hardContent: A partnership arises when two or more persons associate to carry on a for‑profit business as co‑owners. No formalities or written agreement are required; a court may infer a partnership where the parties’ conduct reflects an intent to operate a business together and share in its upside and management, regardless of whether they subjectively intended to form a “partnership.” In deciding whether a partnership exists, courts look first to the parties’ intent to carry on a business as co‑owners, and then to objective indicators such as profit‑sharing, sharing of control, capital contributions, and joint ownership of property. In addition, under the doctrine of partnership by estoppel, even if no actual partnership has been formed, persons may still be treated as partners vis‑à‑vis third parties if they hold themselves or others out as partners, or consent to being held out as partners, and a third party relies on that representation in dealing with them.
cards.mnemonic: Formation: PCJ—Profits, Control, capital, Joint ownership.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) definition and lack of formalities; (2) evidentiary factors and profit-sharing presumption vs lesser factors; (3) partnership by estoppel.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::partnership}} is a {{c2::for‑profit business}} carried on by {{c3::two or more co‑owners}} and can also arise via {{c4::partnership by estoppel}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.topic: Partners' Rights in Property, Profits, & Management
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 003. Partners' Rights in Property, Profits, & Management
cards.front: Partners' Rights in Property, Profits, & Management
cards.backPlain: Partners in a general partnership have three key sets of default rights: 1. Partnership Property – What counts as partnership property? Partnership property includes capital contributed by each partner and all property owned by or purchased with partnership funds. Title in the partnership name or purchase with partnership funds strongly indicates partnership property, and courts may also look at how the property is used, recorded, and maintained. 2. Partners’ Interest in Property – Who owns specific assets? The partnership, as an entity, owns partnership property. Individual partners have no separate ownership interest in specific partnership assets, and their personal creditors cannot directly reach partnership property to satisfy individual debts. Instead, partners hold an economic/transferable interest. 3. Profits, Losses, and Management – Default economic and control rights. Each partner has a transferable interest consisting of her share of profits and losses and the right to receive distributions. Absent agreement, partners share profits (and thus losses) equally and have equal rights in management of the partnership business.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main categories of partners’ default rights in a general partnership regarding property, profits/losses, and management?
cards.cloze: Partners in a general partnership have three key sets of default rights: 1. {{c1::Partnership Property}} – what counts as partnership property and how courts determine it. 2. {{c2::Partners’ Interest in Property}} – the partnership’s ownership of specific assets and limits on partners’ individual rights in those assets. 3. {{c3::Profits, Losses, and Management}} – partners’ transferable economic interests, default sharing of profits/losses, and default equal management rights.
cards.easyContent: Partners’ default rights fall into three buckets: (1) what counts as partnership property, (2) partners’ lack of individual ownership in specific partnership assets (they only have an economic/transferable interest), and (3) default equal sharing of profits and losses and equal management rights unless agreed otherwise.
cards.mediumContent: Partners have three main categories of default rights. First, rules defining partnership property: property contributed by partners or bought with partnership funds and held or treated as partnership property. Second, rules on partners’ interests in that property: the partnership, not the individual partners, owns specific assets, and partners’ personal creditors cannot seize partnership property. Third, default rules on economic and control rights: partners hold a transferable economic interest (profits, losses, distributions), share profits and losses equally absent agreement, and have equal management rights by default.
cards.hardContent: Partners’ default rights in a general partnership can be organized into three main categories. (1) Partnership property: capital contributed by partners and property owned by or purchased with partnership funds is partnership property, with title and source of funds plus use, records, and maintenance as key factors. (2) Partners’ interests in property: the partnership as an entity owns specific partnership assets; individual partners have no separate interest in those assets, and their personal creditors cannot directly reach partnership property. (3) Economic and management rights: each partner instead holds a transferable interest in her share of profits and losses and the right to receive distributions, profits and losses are shared equally absent agreement, and each partner has equal management rights unless the partnership agreement provides otherwise.
cards.mnemonic: P-P-M: Partnership Property, no Personal asset rights, equal Money & Management.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) what counts as partnership property; (2) partners’ lack of specific ownership vs transferable interest; (3) default profit/loss sharing and management rights.
cards.clozeLite: Partners’ default rights fall into three buckets: {{c1::what counts as partnership property}}, {{c2::partners’ lack of individual ownership in specific assets}} (only an {{c3::economic/transferable interest}}), and {{c4::equal sharing of profits, losses, and management rights absent agreement}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.backPlain: Partners owe the partnership and fellow partners the following duties: 1. Duty of loyalty: each partner must 1.1 account for property, profits, or benefits derived in connection with the partnership business; 1.2 refrain from competing with the partnership; and 1.3 refrain from dealing with the partnership as, or on behalf of, a party with an adverse interest to the partnership. 2. Duty of care: each partner must refrain from engaging in misconduct, specifically 2.1 grossly negligent or reckless conduct; 2.2 intentional misconduct; or 2.3 knowing violations of the law. 3. Duty of obedience: partners are agents of the partnership and, as such, must obey all reasonable directions from the partnership. 4. Duty to provide complete and accurate information: partners must provide each other and the partnership complete and accurate information concerning the partnership. 5. Partnership books and information: every partner has a right to inspect and copy partnership financial information. Note: discuss the relevant duty if the facts show malfeasance, misconduct, or disloyalty by a partner.
cards.frontPrompt: What fiduciary duties do partners owe to the partnership and to each other, and what conduct breaches each duty?
cards.cloze: Partners owe the partnership and fellow partners the following duties: 1. {{c1::Duty of loyalty}}: each partner must 1.1 {{c2::account for property, profits, or benefits}} derived in connection with the partnership business; 1.2 {{c3::refrain from competing}} with the partnership; and 1.3 refrain from {{c4::dealing with the partnership as, or on behalf of, a party with an adverse interest}} to the partnership. 2. {{c5::Duty of care}}: each partner must refrain from engaging in misconduct, specifically 2.1 {{c6::grossly negligent or reckless conduct}}; 2.2 {{c7::intentional misconduct}}; or 2.3 {{c8::knowing violations of the law}}. 3. {{c9::Duty of obedience}}: partners are agents of the partnership and, as such, must {{c10::obey all reasonable directions}} from the partnership. 4. {{c11::Duty to provide complete and accurate information}}: partners must provide each other and the partnership {{c12::complete and accurate information}} concerning the partnership. 5. {{c13::Partnership books and information}}: every partner has a {{c14::right to inspect and copy}} partnership financial information. Note: discuss the relevant duty if the facts show {{c15::malfeasance, misconduct, or disloyalty}} by a partner.
cards.easyContent: Partners owe each other and the partnership fiduciary duties of loyalty, care, and obedience, plus duties to provide information and allow inspection of books. Loyalty bars self‑dealing and competition; care bars grossly negligent or intentional misconduct.
cards.mediumContent: Partners owe fiduciary duties to the partnership and to one another. The duty of loyalty requires partners to account for any property, profits, or benefits derived from partnership business, not to compete with the partnership, and not to deal with the partnership on behalf of an adverse party. The duty of care requires partners to avoid grossly negligent, reckless, intentional, or knowing unlawful conduct. As agents, partners also owe a duty of obedience to follow reasonable partnership directions. In addition, partners must provide complete and accurate information about the partnership and must allow other partners to inspect and copy partnership books and financial records.
cards.hardContent: Partners owe the partnership and their co-partners several fiduciary duties. The duty of loyalty requires each partner to account to the partnership for any property, profits, or other benefits derived in connection with partnership business, to refrain from competing with the partnership, and to avoid dealing with the partnership as, or on behalf of, a party with an interest adverse to the partnership. The duty of care obligates partners to refrain from grossly negligent or reckless conduct, intentional misconduct, or knowing violations of the law in connection with partnership affairs. As agents, partners owe a duty of obedience to comply with all reasonable directions of the partnership. Partners also owe a duty to provide complete and accurate information regarding partnership business to the partnership and to fellow partners, and every partner has a right to inspect and copy the partnership’s books and financial information. On an exam, any fact pattern involving partner misconduct, disloyal competition, or concealment of information should trigger a discussion of the relevant fiduciary duties.
cards.mnemonic: Think "LC OBI": Loyalty, Care, Obedience, Books, Information.
cards.clozeLite: Partners owe {{c1::loyalty}}, {{c2::care}}, and {{c3::obedience}}, plus duties to {{c4::provide information}} and {{c5::allow inspection of books}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 005. Liability of Partners & The Partnership
cards.backPlain: 1. Contract liability: all partners are liable for any contract made in the scope of the partnership business and other contracts expressly authorized by the partners. 1.1 Power to bind: a partner can bind the partnership for any transaction in the ordinary course of the partnership business, unless 1.1.1 the partner has no authority to act on behalf of the partnership; and 1.1.2 the other side has knowledge or notice that the partner lacks authority. 1.2 Acts outside ordinary partnership business: acts by individual partners outside the scope of the partnership business do not bind the partnership unless all partners authorize the act. 2. Tort liability: partners are liable for torts committed by a partner or employee if the tort is committed either 2.1 in the ordinary course of partnership business; or 2.2 with authority of the partnership. For example, Partner A can be liable for fraud committed by Partner B in the course of partnership business, even though A had no knowledge or participation in the fraud. 3. Nature and extent of liability: 3.1 all partners are jointly and severally liable. That is, an action can be brought against any one or several of the partners as individuals or against the partnership; and 3.2 all partners are jointly and severally liable for all partnership debts if the partnership cannot satisfy the debts itself.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a partnership (and its partners) liable for contracts and torts, and what is the nature of partners’ liability?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Contract liability}}: all partners are liable for any contract made in the {{c2::scope of the partnership business}} and other contracts {{c3::expressly authorized}} by the partners. 1.1 {{c4::Power to bind}}: a partner can bind the partnership for any transaction in the {{c5::ordinary course of the partnership business}}, unless 1.1.1 the partner has {{c6::no authority}} to act on behalf of the partnership; and 1.1.2 the other side has {{c7::knowledge or notice}} that the partner lacks authority. 1.2 Acts outside ordinary partnership business: acts by individual partners {{c8::outside the scope of the partnership business}} do not bind the partnership unless {{c9::all partners authorize}} the act. 2. {{c10::Tort liability}}: partners are liable for torts committed by a partner or employee if the tort is committed either 2.1 in the {{c11::ordinary course of partnership business}}; or 2.2 with {{c12::authority of the partnership}}. For example, Partner A can be liable for fraud committed by Partner B in the course of partnership business, even though A had no knowledge or participation in the fraud. 3. Nature and extent of liability: 3.1 all partners are {{c13::jointly and severally liable}}. That is, an action can be brought against any one or several of the partners as individuals or against the partnership; and 3.2 all partners are jointly and severally liable for {{c14::all partnership debts}} if the partnership cannot satisfy the debts itself.
cards.easyContent: Partners are personally liable on contracts entered in the ordinary course of partnership business or with authority, and for torts committed in the ordinary course of business or with authority. All partners are jointly and severally liable for partnership debts when the partnership cannot pay.
cards.mediumContent: For contracts, any partner can bind the partnership in transactions within the ordinary course of partnership business or pursuant to express authorization, and all partners are liable on such contracts. A partner does not bind the partnership when acting outside the ordinary course unless all partners authorize the act. For torts, the partnership and partners are liable for torts committed by a partner or employee in the ordinary course of partnership business or with the partnership’s authority, even if an individual partner was unaware of the wrongful act. In all such cases, partners are jointly and severally liable for partnership obligations, so a creditor may sue any one or more partners individually or the partnership itself, and may collect unsatisfied debts from the partners if the partnership’s assets are insufficient.
cards.hardContent: Partners are liable for both contract and tort obligations of the partnership. For contracts, all partners are liable for any contract made within the scope of the partnership business and for contracts expressly authorized by the partners. Any partner has power to bind the partnership in transactions in the ordinary course of the partnership’s business, unless the partner lacks authority and the third party knows or has notice of this lack of authority. Acts by a partner that are outside the ordinary course of the partnership business do not bind the partnership unless all partners authorize the act. For torts, partners are liable for torts committed by a partner or an employee if the tort occurs in the ordinary course of partnership business or with authority of the partnership. Thus, a partner can be liable for another partner’s fraud committed in the course of partnership business even if the first partner had no knowledge of the fraud. The nature of this liability is joint and several: an action may be brought against any one or more partners or against the partnership entity, and if the partnership cannot satisfy its debts, all partners are jointly and severally liable for the remaining partnership obligations.
cards.mnemonic: COAT J/S: Contracts, Ordinary-course, Authorized Torts → Joint & Several.
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::contracts}}, any partner can bind the partnership in the {{c2::ordinary course of business}} or with {{c3::express authorization}}. Partners are {{c4::jointly and severally liable}} for such {{c5::contract and tort}} obligations.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.backPlain: In partnership law, there are two key end-of-relationship concepts: 1. Dissociation (partner leaves, partnership may continue): - A dissociation occurs when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership business. - It can be triggered by withdrawal, an agreed-upon event, valid expulsion, bankruptcy, or similar events. - Dissociation ends the partner’s rights to profits and management and cuts off fiduciary duties going forward, though duties remain as to matters arising before dissociation. - If the partnership continues as a going concern, it must buy out the dissociated partner’s interest. 2. Dissolution (partnership ends as a going concern): - Dissolution is the termination of the partnership as a going concern. - It may be triggered by agreed-upon events, expiration of a term, a judicial decree, or a partner’s notice in an at-will partnership. - After dissolution, the partnership exists only to wind up, liquidate assets to cash, pay creditors first, and then distribute any remaining amounts to the partners individually.
cards.frontPrompt: In partnership law, how do dissociation and dissolution differ, and what are the basic consequences of each?
cards.cloze: In partnership law, there are two key end-of-relationship concepts: 1. {{c1::Dissociation}} (partner leaves, partnership may continue): - A dissociation occurs when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership business. - It can be triggered by {{c2::withdrawal, agreed events, valid expulsion, bankruptcy}}, or similar events. - Dissociation ends the partner’s rights to {{c3::profits}} and {{c4::management}} and cuts off {{c5::fiduciary duties going forward}}, while duties remain for pre-dissociation matters. - If the partnership continues, it must {{c6::buy out the dissociated partner’s interest}}. 2. {{c7::Dissolution}} (partnership ends as a going concern): - Dissolution is the {{c8::termination of the partnership as a going concern}}. - It may be triggered by {{c9::agreed events, expiration of a term, judicial decree, or a partner’s notice in an at-will partnership}}. - After dissolution, the partnership exists only to {{c10::wind up}}, {{c11::liquidate assets}}, pay {{c12::creditors first}}, and then {{c13::distribute remaining assets to partners}}.
cards.easyContent: Dissociation is when a partner leaves the partnership but the firm may continue with a buyout of that partner’s interest. Dissolution is when the partnership ends as a going concern and only remains to wind up—liquidate assets, pay creditors first, then distribute what’s left to partners.
cards.mediumContent: Dissociation occurs when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership, such as by withdrawal, agreed events, valid expulsion, or bankruptcy. It ends that partner’s rights to profits and management and their prospective fiduciary duties (though duties remain as to prior matters), and if the partnership continues, it must buy out the partner’s interest. Dissolution is the termination of the partnership as a going concern, triggered by agreed events, expiration of a term, a judicial decree, or a partner’s notice in an at-will partnership; after dissolution, the partnership only exists to wind up, liquidate assets, pay creditors first, and distribute any remaining amounts to partners.
cards.hardContent: Dissociation is any partner ceasing to be associated in carrying on the partnership business. It can be triggered by the partner’s voluntary withdrawal, the happening of an agreed-upon event, valid expulsion, the partner’s bankruptcy, or similar events. Dissociation terminates the partner’s rights to profits and management and ends prospective fiduciary duties, while duties persist as to matters arising before dissociation. If the partnership continues as a going concern, it must purchase the dissociated partner’s interest. Dissolution is the termination of the partnership as a going concern. It is caused by events such as the happening of an agreed-upon event, expiration of a term in the partnership agreement, issuance of a judicial decree, or a partner’s notice in an at-will partnership. After dissolution, the partnership continues solely to wind up its affairs: it must cease new business, wind up activities, reduce assets to cash, pay liabilities first to creditors, and then distribute any remaining assets to the partners individually.
cards.mnemonic: DiSsociation: Single partner out; DiSsolution: whole partnership out.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into two children: (1) dissociation (definition, causes, effects, buyout) and (2) dissolution (causes, at-will dissolution, and winding-up process including asset distribution).
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Dissociation}} is when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership and the firm {{c2::must buy out}} that partner’s interest if it continues. {{c3::Dissolution}} terminates the partnership as a {{c4::going concern}} so it exists only to {{c5::wind up, liquidate assets, pay creditors first, then distribute to partners}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.backPlain: A limited liability partnership (LLP) limits a partner's personal liability for the partnership's obligations and actions. 1. Formation: Any partnership can become an LLP upon: 1.1 Approval of the partners by vote; and 1.2 Filing a statement of qualification with the state containing partner names, addresses, the LLP election, and the effective date. 2. Liability: 2.1 A partner in an LLP is not personally liable for partnership obligations of any sort; but 2.2 Every partner remains personally liable for her own acts or acts that she supervises or directs. 3. Rights and obligations: The financial rights and obligations of LLP partners are the same as in a standard general partnership.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a limited liability partnership (LLP), how is it formed, and how does partner liability in an LLP differ from a general partnership?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::limited liability partnership (LLP)}} limits a partner's personal liability for the partnership's obligations and actions. 1. {{c2::Formation}}: Any partnership can become an LLP upon: 1.1 {{c3::Approval of the partners by vote}}; and 1.2 {{c4::Filing a statement of qualification}} with the state containing partner names, addresses, the LLP election, and the effective date. 2. {{c5::Liability}}: 2.1 A partner in an LLP is {{c6::not personally liable for partnership obligations}} of any sort; but 2.2 Every partner remains personally liable for {{c7::her own acts}} or acts that she {{c8::supervises or directs}}. 3. {{c9::Rights and obligations}}: The financial rights and obligations of LLP partners are the same as in a {{c10::standard general partnership}}.
cards.easyContent: A limited liability partnership (LLP) is a partnership where partners are not personally liable for the firm’s obligations, only for their own acts. Any partnership can elect LLP status by partner approval and filing a statement of qualification with the state.
cards.mediumContent: An LLP is a partnership form that shields partners from personal liability for partnership obligations, while leaving them personally liable for their own acts and those they supervise or direct. To form an LLP, the partners must approve by vote and file a statement of qualification with the state listing partner names and addresses, the LLP election, and the effective date. Financial rights and obligations in an LLP are the same as in a general partnership.
cards.hardContent: A limited liability partnership (LLP) is a partnership in which partners receive limited liability protection: a partner is not personally liable for partnership obligations of any sort, but remains personally liable for her own wrongful acts and for acts she supervises or directs. Any existing partnership can become an LLP if the partners approve the change by vote and file a statement of qualification with the state authorities, which must include the partners’ names and addresses, the LLP election, and the effective date. The LLP otherwise functions like a general partnership, and the partners’ financial rights and obligations are the same as in a standard general partnership.
cards.mnemonic: LLP: Limited for partnership debts, Personal for your own.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::LLP}} shields partners from {{c2::personal liability for partnership obligations}} but not for {{c3::their own acts or those they supervise}}; it’s formed by {{c4::partner approval}} and {{c5::filing a statement of qualification with the state}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.backPlain: A limited partnership contains two types of partners, general and limited partners, and must contain one or more of each type. 1. Rights, duties, and obligations: 1.1 General partners: Manage and control day-to-day operations and owe the same fiduciary duties as partners in a general partnership. 1.2 Limited partners: Usually passive investors with limited authority. They owe no fiduciary duties to the partnership, and unless the partnership agreement provides otherwise, they may compete with the partnership and have interests adverse to the partnership. 2. Liability: 2.1 General partners: Personally, jointly, and severally liable for all partnership obligations. Incoming general partners are not liable for obligations the partnership incurred before they became general partners. 2.2 Limited partners: Liable only to the extent of their investment. 3. Formation: A limited partnership is formed by filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state. The certificate generally must contain the names and addresses of each general partner and their signatures.
cards.frontPrompt: In a limited partnership, how do general partners and limited partners differ in management rights, fiduciary duties, and liability, and how is a limited partnership formed?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::limited partnership}} contains two types of partners, {{c2::general}} and {{c3::limited}} partners, and must contain one or more of each type. 1. {{c4::Rights, duties, and obligations}}: 1.1 {{c5::General partners}}: Manage and control day-to-day operations and owe the same {{c6::fiduciary duties}} as partners in a general partnership. 1.2 {{c7::Limited partners}}: Usually passive investors with limited authority. They owe {{c8::no fiduciary duties}} to the partnership, and unless the partnership agreement provides otherwise, they may {{c9::compete with the partnership}} and have interests {{c10::adverse to the partnership}}. 2. {{c11::Liability}}: 2.1 General partners: {{c12::Personally, jointly, and severally liable}} for all partnership obligations. Incoming general partners are not liable for obligations the partnership incurred before they became general partners. 2.2 Limited partners: Liable only to the extent of their {{c13::investment}}. 3. {{c14::Formation}}: A limited partnership is formed by {{c15::filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state}}. The certificate generally must contain the {{c16::names and addresses of each general partner}} and their {{c17::signatures}}.
cards.easyContent: A limited partnership has at least one general partner, who manages and is personally liable, and at least one limited partner, who is usually a passive investor liable only up to their investment. It is created by filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state identifying the general partners.
cards.mediumContent: A limited partnership must have at least one general partner and one limited partner. General partners manage day-to-day operations and owe standard fiduciary duties, and they are personally, jointly, and severally liable for partnership obligations (though new general partners are not liable for pre-admission obligations). Limited partners are typically passive investors with limited authority, owe no fiduciary duties to the partnership, and absent agreement limits can compete or hold adverse interests; they are liable only to the extent of their investment. Formation requires filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state, listing the names and addresses of each general partner and their signatures.
cards.hardContent: A limited partnership is a statutory business form that must include at least one general partner and at least one limited partner. General partners manage and control the partnership’s day-to-day operations and owe the same fiduciary duties as partners in a general partnership. They are personally, jointly, and severally liable for all partnership obligations, although incoming general partners are not liable for obligations incurred before they became general partners. Limited partners are usually passive investors with limited authority; they owe no fiduciary duties to the partnership and, unless the partnership agreement provides otherwise, may compete with the partnership and hold interests adverse to it. Limited partners’ liability is limited to the amount of their investment. A limited partnership is formed by filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state, generally including the names and addresses of each general partner and their signatures.
cards.mnemonic: GP: General Power & Personal liability; LP: Limited Power & Limited liability.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::limited partnership}} must have at least {{c2::one general and one limited partner}}; {{c3::general partners manage and have personal liability}}, while {{c4::limited partners are passive with liability limited to investment}}; it is formed by {{c5::filing a certificate of limited partnership with the state}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 002-1. Partnership Formation – Core Rule & Formalities
cards.backPlain: Core definition: • A partnership is formed when two or more people associate to carry on a for-profit business as co-owners. No formalities required: • No formal or written agreement is required. • The parties do not need to intend to form a “partnership” as such. • A partnership can be found where their conduct shows an intent to associate as co-owners in a for-profit business.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the core definition of a partnership, and are any formalities or specific intent to create a partnership required?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::partnership}} is formed when {{c2::two or more people}} associate to carry on a {{c3::for-profit business}} as {{c4::co-owners}}. No {{c5::formal or written agreement}} is required, and the parties do not need to {{c6::intend to form a “partnership”}} as such. A partnership can be found where their {{c7::conduct shows an intent to associate as co-owners}} in a for-profit business.
cards.easyContent: A partnership exists when two or more people carry on a for‑profit business as co‑owners. No written agreement or specific intent to form a “partnership” is required; courts can infer it from conduct.
cards.mediumContent: A partnership is created when two or more persons associate to carry on a for‑profit business as co‑owners. There are no required formalities—no written agreement or use of the term “partnership” is needed. What matters is that their conduct reflects an intent to run a for‑profit business together as co‑owners.
cards.hardContent: A partnership forms when two or more persons associate to carry on a for‑profit business as co‑owners. No statute or common law rule requires a formal filing or written partnership agreement, and the parties need not subjectively intend to create a “partnership” entity. Instead, the existence of a partnership may be inferred from their conduct—such as jointly operating a business, sharing its upside, and exercising co‑management—showing an intent to associate as co‑owners in a for‑profit enterprise.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::partnership}} exists when {{c2::two or more persons}} carry on a {{c3::for‑profit business}} as {{c4::co‑owners}}, and {{c5::no formalities or specific intent}} are required.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 002-2. Partnership Formation – Proving Existence & Factors
cards.backPlain: Proving a partnership exists: • Parties’ intent: If the parties intended to carry on a business as co-owners, a partnership is formed, even if they did not intend to be in a “partnership.” Primary factor – Profit-sharing presumption: • A person who receives a share of a business’s profits is presumed to be a partner. • Exceptions: No presumption arises if the profits are received as payment of: – a debt; – rent; – wages; or – services rendered (i.e., as a business expense rather than a profit distribution). Lesser, non-presumptive factors (support but do not create a presumption): • Sharing of control/management of the business; • Capital investment or contributions; and • Joint ownership of property used in the business.
cards.frontPrompt: How do courts determine whether a partnership exists, and what is the profit‑sharing presumption and its exceptions, along with the lesser factors courts may consider?
cards.cloze: To prove a partnership exists, courts look first to the parties’ {{c1::intent}} to carry on a business as {{c2::co-owners}}; a partnership can be formed even if they did not intend to be in a “partnership.” Primary factor – {{c3::Profit-sharing}} presumption: • A person who receives a share of a business’s profits is {{c4::presumed to be a partner}}. • Exceptions: There is {{c5::no presumption}} when profits are received as payment of a {{c6::debt}}, {{c7::rent}}, {{c8::wages}}, or {{c9::services rendered}} (i.e., as a business expense rather than a profit distribution). Lesser, non-presumptive factors: • {{c10::Sharing of control/management}} of the business; • {{c11::Capital investment or contributions}}; and • {{c12::Joint ownership of property}} used in the business.
cards.easyContent: Courts mainly ask whether the parties intended to run a business as co‑owners. Sharing in profits creates a presumption of partnership, unless the payment is for a debt, rent, wages, or services. Sharing control, contributing capital, and jointly owning property are lesser factors that support, but don’t presume, partnership formation.
cards.mediumContent: To determine if a partnership exists, courts focus on whether the parties intended to carry on a business as co‑owners. When that is unclear, a strong indicator is receipt of a share of the business’s profits, which creates a presumption of partnership. The presumption does not arise when the payment is for a debt, rent, wages, or services rendered (i.e., a business expense). Courts may also consider lesser factors—sharing control, capital contributions, and joint ownership of property—which can support but do not by themselves create a presumption of partnership.
cards.hardContent: In disputed-formation cases, courts look first to the parties’ intent to carry on a business as co‑owners; objective manifestations control over subjective labels. When intent is ambiguous, a key evidentiary factor is profit-sharing: receipt of a share of the business’s profits gives rise to a presumption that the recipient is a partner. That presumption is rebutted and does not arise at all when the profits are received as payment of a debt, rent, wages, or services rendered—i.e., in satisfaction of business expenses rather than as a distribution of residual profits. Courts may also weigh additional, non-presumptive indicators such as shared control or management of the business, capital investments, and joint ownership of business property; these factors may support a finding of partnership but do not independently create a legal presumption of its existence.
cards.mnemonic: PCJ: Profits, plus Control, Capital, Joint ownership as lesser factors.
cards.clozeLite: Courts ask if parties {{c1::intended to carry on a business as co-owners}}; {{c2::profit-sharing}} presumptively shows partnership (except {{c3::debt, rent, wages, or services}}), while {{c4::control, capital, and joint ownership}} are lesser, non-presumptive factors.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 002-3. Partnership Formation – Partnership by Estoppel
cards.backPlain: Partnership by estoppel (no true partnership, but liability as if there were one): • Even where no actual partnership exists, parties may be held liable to third parties as if they were partners if: 1) They actively hold themselves or others out as partners, or consent to being held out as partners; and 2) A third party relies on that holding out in dealing with them. Effect: • For that transaction, the law treats the parties as if a partnership existed, making them potentially jointly and severally liable as partners to the relying third party.
cards.frontPrompt: What is partnership by estoppel, and under what circumstances will parties be treated as partners even though no actual partnership exists?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::partnership by estoppel}}, even where no actual partnership exists, parties may be held liable as if they were partners if: • They {{c2::hold themselves or others out as partners}} or {{c3::consent to being held out as partners}}; and • A {{c4::third party relies}} on that holding out in dealing with them. Effect: For that transaction, the law treats them as if a {{c5::partnership}} existed, potentially making them {{c6::jointly and severally liable}} as partners to the relying third party.
cards.easyContent: Partnership by estoppel makes people liable as if they were partners when they represent themselves or others as partners (or consent to it) and a third party relies on that in dealing with them.
cards.mediumContent: Partnership by estoppel applies when there is no actual partnership but someone holds themselves or another out as a partner, or consents to being held out, and a third party reasonably relies on that representation in entering a transaction. In that situation, the law can treat the parties as partners for that transaction, exposing them to partner‑level liability.
cards.hardContent: The doctrine of partnership by estoppel addresses situations where no true partnership has formed but the conduct or representations of the parties create the appearance of one. If a person represents themselves or another as a partner, or knowingly consents to being held out as a partner, and a third party relies on that ostensible partnership status in extending credit or otherwise dealing with the enterprise, the law may estop the parties from denying the existence of a partnership as against that third party. The effect is to impose liability as if a partnership existed for the particular transaction, often resulting in joint and several liability equivalent to that of actual partners.
cards.mnemonic: Estoppel: hold out as partner, held liable as partner.
cards.clozeLite: Partnership by {{c1::estoppel}} applies when someone {{c2::holds themselves or another out as a partner}}, a third party {{c3::reasonably relies}}, and they face {{c4::partner-level liability for that transaction}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.topic: Partnership Property – What Counts as Partnership Property
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 003-1. Partnership Property – What Counts as Partnership Property
cards.front: Partnership Property – What Counts as Partnership Property
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of partnership property • Partnership property consists of capital contributed by each partner and all property owned by the partnership. • All other property is individual property of the partners. 2. Property deemed to be partnership property • Anything titled in the partnership name. • Anything titled in the name of one or more partners in their capacity as partnership members. 3. Property presumed to be partnership property • Property purchased with partnership funds is presumed to be partnership property, regardless of who has title. 4. Other factors courts consider (when title/funds are unclear) • Use of the property by the partnership. • Entry of the property in partnership books. • Improvement and maintenance of the property with partnership funds.
cards.frontPrompt: How do you determine whether particular property is partnership property rather than a partner’s individual property?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition of {{c1::partnership property}} • Partnership property consists of {{c2::capital contributed}} by each partner and all property {{c3::owned by the partnership}}. • All other property is {{c4::individual property}} of the partners. 2. Property {{c5::deemed}} to be partnership property • Anything {{c6::titled in the partnership name}}. • Anything titled in the name of one or more partners in their capacity as {{c7::partnership members}}. 3. Property {{c8::presumed}} to be partnership property • Property {{c9::purchased with partnership funds}} is presumed to be partnership property, regardless of who has title. 4. Other factors courts consider (when title/funds are unclear) • {{c10::Use of the property by the partnership}}. • {{c11::Entry of the property in partnership books}}. • {{c12::Improvement and maintenance}} of the property with {{c13::partnership funds}}.
cards.easyContent: Partnership property is capital contributed by the partners and property owned by or bought with partnership funds. Title in the partnership name or purchase with partnership funds strongly indicates partnership property, and courts also look to how the property is used, recorded, and maintained.
cards.mediumContent: Partnership property includes capital contributions and all property owned by the partnership. Property is deemed partnership property if it is titled in the partnership name or in partners’ names in their capacity as partners. Property purchased with partnership funds is presumed to be partnership property even if title is in an individual’s name. When these indicators are absent, courts look at how the property is used by the partnership, how it is recorded in the books, and whether it is improved or maintained with partnership funds. Anything else is individual property.
cards.hardContent: To determine whether property belongs to the partnership or to individual partners, start with the definition: partnership property consists of capital contributed by each partner and all property owned by the partnership; all other property is individual. Property is deemed partnership property if it is titled in the partnership’s name or in the name of one or more partners explicitly in their capacity as partnership members. Property purchased with partnership funds is presumed to be partnership property regardless of who holds title. If title and the source of funds are unclear, courts consider factors such as whether the partnership uses the property for its business, whether it is entered on the partnership’s books, and whether partnership funds are used to improve or maintain it.
cards.mnemonic: Title, Funds, Use: how it’s titled, who paid, how partnership uses it.
cards.clozeLite: Property is {{c1::partnership property}} if {{c2::titled in the partnership name}} or {{c3::bought with partnership funds}}; {{c4::otherwise it’s individual property}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.topic: Partners’ Interest in Partnership Property vs Transferable Interest
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 003-2. Partners’ Interest in Partnership Property vs Transferable Interest
cards.front: Partners’ Interest in Partnership Property vs Transferable Interest
cards.backPlain: 1. No individual interest in specific partnership property • Partners have no individual ownership interest in specific items of partnership property. • The partnership, as an entity, owns the property. 2. Protection against partners’ personal creditors • Because partners lack a separate interest in specific partnership assets, a partner’s personal creditors cannot reach partnership property to satisfy that partner’s personal debts. 3. Partner’s transferable interest • Instead of an interest in specific property, each partner has a transferable interest consisting of: – Her share of partnership profits and losses; and – Her right to receive distributions from the partnership. • This transferable interest is a distinct economic interest that can generally be assigned or subject to a charging order, but it does not give the transferee management rights.
cards.frontPrompt: What interest does a partner have (and not have) in specific partnership property, and what is the partner’s transferable interest?
cards.cloze: 1. No individual interest in specific partnership property • Partners have {{c1::no individual ownership interest}} in specific items of partnership property. • The {{c2::partnership, as an entity}}, owns the property. 2. Protection against partners’ personal creditors • Because partners lack a separate interest in specific partnership assets, a partner’s {{c3::personal creditors}} {{c4::cannot reach partnership property}} to satisfy that partner’s personal debts. 3. Partner’s {{c5::transferable interest}} • Each partner instead has a transferable interest consisting of: – Her share of partnership {{c6::profits and losses}}; and – Her right to receive {{c7::distributions}} from the partnership. • This transferable interest is a {{c8::distinct economic interest}} that can be assigned or made subject to a charging order, but it {{c9::does not confer management rights}} on the transferee.
cards.easyContent: Partners do not own specific partnership assets; the partnership does. A partner’s personal creditors therefore cannot seize partnership property. Instead, a partner owns a transferable economic interest: her share of profits and losses and the right to receive distributions, which can be assigned but does not carry management rights.
cards.mediumContent: Partners have no individual ownership interest in specific partnership property; the partnership entity owns those assets. Because of this, a partner’s personal creditors cannot directly levy on partnership property to satisfy that partner’s debts. The partner’s property right is instead a transferable economic interest: her share of profits and losses and her right to receive distributions. That interest can typically be assigned or made subject to a charging order, but the transferee does not automatically step into the partner’s shoes for management or voting rights.
cards.hardContent: In a general partnership, specific assets used in the business are owned by the partnership as an entity, not by the partners individually. As a result, partners have no separate, individual interest in specific partnership property and cannot transfer or encumber those assets as if they were personally owned. Correspondingly, a partner’s personal creditors cannot reach partnership property to satisfy the partner’s individual obligations; they must instead proceed against the partner’s economic rights. Each partner holds a transferable interest made up of her share of partnership profits and losses and her right to receive distributions. This transferable interest is essentially an economic stake that may be assigned or subjected to a charging order in favor of a creditor, but such a transfer does not itself convey management or control rights in the partnership.
cards.mnemonic: EPIC: Entity Property, Individual Cash (profits only).
cards.clozeLite: Partnership {{c1::property is owned by the entity}}, and a partner’s {{c2::personal creditors}} cannot reach it; a partner instead has a {{c3::transferable economic interest}} in {{c4::profits, losses, and distributions}} only.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.topic: Default Profit/Loss Sharing and Management Rights
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 003-3. Default Profit/Loss Sharing and Management Rights
cards.front: Default Profit/Loss Sharing and Management Rights
cards.backPlain: 1. Partner’s economic (transferable) interest • Each partner has a transferable interest consisting of her share of partnership profits and losses and her right to receive distributions. 2. Default share of profits and losses • Each partner’s share of profits is equal absent an alternative agreement. • Each partner must contribute to partnership losses in proportion to her share of profits (so by default, losses are also shared equally). 3. Default management rights • Absent an alternative agreement, all partners have equal rights in the management of the partnership business. • Management rights are distinct from the transferable economic interest and generally cannot be transferred without consent of the other partners.
cards.frontPrompt: Absent an agreement, how do partners share profits and losses, what is their economic interest, and what are their default management rights?
cards.cloze: 1. Partner’s economic ({{c1::transferable}}) interest • Each partner has a transferable interest consisting of her share of partnership {{c2::profits and losses}} and her right to receive {{c3::distributions}}. 2. Default share of profits and losses • Each partner’s share of {{c4::profits}} is {{c5::equal}} absent an alternative agreement. • Each partner must contribute to partnership {{c6::losses}} in proportion to her {{c7::share of profits}} (so by default, losses are shared equally). 3. Default management rights • Absent an alternative agreement, all partners have {{c8::equal rights in the management}} of the partnership business. • Management rights are {{c9::distinct from the transferable economic interest}} and generally {{c10::cannot be transferred}} without consent of the other partners.
cards.easyContent: By default, each partner has an equal economic interest—an equal share of profits and losses and the right to receive distributions—and equal management rights. Partners can change these defaults by agreement, but management rights are separate from the transferable economic interest.
cards.mediumContent: Every partner holds a transferable economic interest made up of her share of profits and losses and the right to receive distributions. If the partnership agreement is silent, profits are shared equally, and losses follow profits—so they are equal as well. Separately, management rights are also equal by default; each partner has an equal voice in running the business. These management rights are distinct from, and generally not freely transferable with, the economic interest.
cards.hardContent: In the absence of a contrary agreement, each partner’s economic interest in a general partnership consists of an equal share of the partnership’s profits and the obligation to bear losses in proportion to that share—so losses are also shared equally by default. This economic interest includes the right to receive distributions and is transferable as an economic right. However, management and control rights are governed by a separate default rule: all partners have equal rights in the management of the partnership business unless the partnership agreement reallocates control. These management rights do not automatically follow a transfer of the economic interest and typically cannot be assigned without the consent of the remaining partners.
cards.mnemonic: Default E-E-E: Equal profits, Equal losses, Equal management.
cards.clozeLite: By default, partners share {{c1::profits equally}}, and {{c2::losses follow profits}}. Each has a {{c3::transferable economic interest}} and {{c4::equal management rights}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.topic: Dissociation – Definition, Causes, Effects, and Buyout
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 006-1. Dissociation – Definition, Causes, Effects, and Buyout
cards.front: Dissociation – Definition, Causes, Effects, and Buyout
cards.backPlain: 1. Dissociation (any partner ceasing to be associated in carrying on the partnership business): 1.1 Definition: Dissociation occurs when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership business. 1.2 Causes: Dissociation can be caused by: - The partner’s voluntary desire to withdraw; - The happening of an agreed-upon event; - Valid expulsion of the partner under the partnership agreement or the statute; - The partner’s bankruptcy; or - Similar significant events. 1.3 Effects: - Dissociation terminates the dissociated partner’s legal relationship with the partnership as a current partner. - The partner’s rights to share in profits and to participate in management end. - The partner’s fiduciary duties terminate prospectively, but the partner remains responsible for fiduciary duties with respect to matters that occurred before dissociation. 1.4 Buyout obligation: - If the partnership continues its business after a partner’s dissociation (i.e., the entity does not dissolve), it must purchase or buy out the dissociated partner’s partnership interest for its value.
cards.frontPrompt: In partnership law, what is dissociation, what events cause it, what are its legal effects on the partner’s rights and duties, and what buyout obligation arises if the partnership continues?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissociation}} (any partner ceasing to be associated in carrying on the partnership business): 1.1 Definition: Dissociation occurs when a partner {{c2::ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership business}}. 1.2 Causes: Dissociation can be caused by: - The partner’s voluntary {{c3::withdrawal}}; - The happening of an {{c4::agreed-upon event}}; - {{c5::Valid expulsion}} of the partner under the agreement or statute; - The partner’s {{c6::bankruptcy}}; or - Similar significant events. 1.3 Effects: - Dissociation terminates the dissociated partner’s {{c7::legal relationship with the partnership as a current partner}}. - The partner’s rights to {{c8::profits}} and {{c9::management}} end. - The partner’s {{c10::fiduciary duties}} terminate prospectively, but remain with respect to {{c11::matters occurring before dissociation}}. 1.4 Buyout obligation: - If the partnership {{c12::continues its business}} after dissociation, it must {{c13::purchase the dissociated partner’s partnership interest}} for its value.
cards.easyContent: Dissociation is when a partner stops being associated in carrying on the partnership business. It can occur by withdrawal, agreed events, expulsion, bankruptcy, or similar events. The partner loses profit and management rights, their fiduciary duties end going forward (but not for prior acts), and if the partnership continues, it must buy out the partner’s interest.
cards.mediumContent: Dissociation occurs when a partner ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership. It can be triggered by the partner’s voluntary withdrawal, an agreed-upon event, valid expulsion, the partner’s bankruptcy, or similar events. Dissociation ends the partner’s legal relationship as a current partner, including rights to profits and management, and cuts off fiduciary duties prospectively, though duties remain as to matters arising before dissociation. If the partnership continues as a going concern, it must buy out the dissociated partner’s interest for its value.
cards.hardContent: Dissociation is any partner ceasing to be associated in carrying on the partnership business. It can result from (1) the partner’s voluntary desire to withdraw, (2) the occurrence of an agreed-upon event specified in the partnership agreement or statute, (3) valid expulsion under the agreement or statutory grounds, (4) the partner’s bankruptcy, or (5) similar significant events. Upon dissociation, the partner’s status as a current partner terminates: the partner loses rights to share in ongoing profits and to participate in management. The partner’s fiduciary duties—such as the duties of loyalty and care—terminate prospectively, but continue to govern matters arising or transactions entered into before dissociation. If the remaining partners choose to continue the business rather than dissolve, the continuing partnership must purchase (buy out) the dissociated partner’s partnership interest for its value under the applicable statute or agreement.
cards.mnemonic: DISSOCIATE: Done In Share, Status Out, Capital In, All Tied Ends.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 1 of 2 for partnerships-006: focuses on dissociation (definition, causes, effects, and buyout).
cards.clozeLite: Dissociation occurs when a partner {{c1::ceases to be associated in carrying on the partnership}}, which {{c2::terminates profit and management rights}} and {{c3::cuts off fiduciary duties prospectively}}; if the business continues, the partnership must {{c4::buy out the dissociated partner’s interest}}.

cards.subject: Partnerships
cards.topic: Dissolution and Winding Up – Causes and Asset Distribution
cards.rawHeader: Partnerships 006-2. Dissolution and Winding Up – Causes and Asset Distribution
cards.front: Dissolution and Winding Up – Causes and Asset Distribution
cards.backPlain: 2. Dissolution (termination of the partnership as a going concern) and winding up: 2.1 Dissolution – causes: - Dissolution is the termination of the partnership as a going concern. - It is caused by the happening of an agreed-upon event, expiration of a term in the partnership agreement, issuance of a judicial decree, or similar events. - In an at-will partnership (formed with no specific undertaking or definite term), any partner can cause dissolution at any time by providing notice of dissolution. 2.2 Winding up – process and distribution: 2.2.1 After dissolution, the partnership must cease taking on new business, wind up its existing business activities, and liquidate assets (reduce them to cash). 2.2.2 The partnership continues in existence only for the limited purpose of winding up until the winding-up process is complete. 2.2.3 Asset distribution priority: - First, liabilities are paid to creditors (including partner-creditors, if applicable). - Then, any remaining amounts are distributed to partners individually, typically according to their partnership interests.
cards.frontPrompt: In partnership law, what events cause dissolution of a partnership (including at-will partnerships), and what happens during winding up, especially regarding asset distribution?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Dissolution}} (termination of the partnership as a going concern) and winding up: 2.1 Dissolution – causes: - Dissolution is the {{c2::termination of the partnership as a going concern}}. - It is caused by the happening of an {{c3::agreed-upon event}}, {{c4::expiration of a term}} in the partnership agreement, {{c5::issuance of a judicial decree}}, or similar events. - In an {{c6::at-will partnership}} (with no specific undertaking or definite term), any partner can cause dissolution at any time by providing {{c7::notice of dissolution}}. 2.2 Winding up – process and distribution: 2.2.1 After dissolution, the partnership must {{c8::cease new business}}, {{c9::wind up existing activities}}, and {{c10::liquidate assets to cash}}. 2.2.2 The partnership continues in existence only for the {{c11::limited purpose of winding up}} until the {{c12::winding-up process is complete}}. 2.2.3 Asset distribution priority: - First, liabilities are paid to {{c13::creditors}}. - Then, any remaining amounts are distributed to {{c14::partners individually}}, typically according to their {{c15::partnership interests}}.
cards.easyContent: Dissolution ends the partnership as a going concern. It’s triggered by agreed events, expiration of a term, a judicial decree, or a partner’s notice in an at-will partnership. After dissolution, the partnership only exists to wind up: it stops taking new business, liquidates assets to cash, pays creditors first, and distributes any remainder to the partners.
cards.mediumContent: Dissolution is the termination of the partnership as a going concern. It is caused by agreed-upon events, expiration of a partnership term, issuance of a judicial decree, or similar events. In an at-will partnership, any partner can cause dissolution at any time by giving notice of dissolution. Once dissolved, the partnership continues solely to wind up: it must stop taking on new business, wind up existing activities, reduce assets to cash, and follow the priority of payment—liabilities to creditors first, then any remaining funds to partners individually according to their interests.
cards.hardContent: Dissolution marks the termination of the partnership as a going concern. It occurs when an agreed-upon event happens, a fixed term in the partnership agreement expires, a judicial decree (such as one based on impracticability or misconduct) issues, or similar events occur. In an at-will partnership—formed without a specific undertaking or definite term—any partner may unilaterally cause dissolution by giving notice of dissolution. After dissolution, the partnership’s role is limited to winding up: it should cease entering into new business, wind up existing business affairs, and liquidate assets to cash. During winding up, the partnership continues in existence only for this limited purpose until the process is complete. Once assets are reduced to cash, the partnership must first pay liabilities to creditors (including partner-creditors, under most statutes). Any surplus remaining after paying creditors is then distributed to the partners individually, usually in proportion to their partnership interests or capital accounts.
cards.mnemonic: DISSOLVE: Decide, Inform, Stop, Sell, Obligations first, Leftovers to partners, Vanish Entity.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 2 of 2 for partnerships-006: focuses on dissolution triggers and the winding-up and distribution process.
cards.clozeLite: Dissolution ends the {{c1::partnership as a going concern}}. In an {{c2::at-will partnership}}, any partner may {{c3::cause dissolution by notice}}; then assets pay {{c4::creditors first}} and {{c5::partners last}}.
